title: 109_hr1600
content: The Act titled "Abandoned Mine Lands Reclamation Reform Act of 2005" amends the Surface Mining Act. Amendments to Section 401 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include redesignating paragraphs and adjusting language for achieving the purposes of transfers under section 402(h). Section 712(b) is also amended to reflect changes in subsections. Amendments to Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include changes to subsections regarding adjustments in numbers and dates. Amendments to Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 involve ensuring compliance with priorities set forth in section 403(a) for grants to States and Indian tribes until certification is made under section 411(a). Subsection (g)(3) is modified by adjusting references and adding a new provision for paragraph (8). Subsection (g)(5) is also amended by changing numbers from 40 to 60. Amendments to Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 involve adjusting references and adding provisions for grants to States and Indian tribes. Subsection (g)(5) is amended by changing numbers from 40 to 60, and subsection (g)(6) allows States with approved abandoned mine reclamation programs to retain up to 10 percent of annual grants without a 3-year limitation. The text discusses the establishment of an acid mine drainage abatement and treatment fund under State law to address the effects of acid mine drainage in hydrologic units affected by coal mining practices. The term "qualified hydrologic unit" is defined as a unit impacted by acid mine drainage that adversely affects biological resources and meets certain criteria outlined in the paragraph. The text discusses the priorities for State expenditures from the forfeiture of bonds to abate and treat acid mine drainage. States can use grants for reclamation of eligible lands and waters before completing other reclamation projects, as long as funds are used in conjunction. Amendments to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include ensuring annual grant awards of at least $2,000,000 to each State and Indian tribe for reclamation projects. This applies specifically to the State of Tennessee. Amendments to Section 403 involve removing references to "general welfare" and "health, safety" in the prioritization of State expenditures from bond forfeitures for acid mine drainage abatement and treatment. Amendments to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 involve changes such as modifying language in paragraphs (2) and (3), updating subsection (b) regarding water supply restoration, and adding approval requirements in subsection (c). Section 406(h) is also amended. Amendments to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include changes to sections 406, 408, and 411. These changes involve updating language, authorizing appropriations to the Secretary of Agriculture, and modifying ownership requirements. The amendments to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include changes to sections 406, 408, and 411. One change allows the Secretary to make certifications on behalf of states or tribes if all reclamation projects have been completed. Another change involves the state share for certain certified states from funds paid into the Treasury. The amendments to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include changes to sections 406, 408, and 411. One change allows the Secretary to make certifications on behalf of states or tribes if all reclamation projects have been completed. Another change involves payments to qualified States based on unappropriated amounts allocated under section 402(g)(1)(A) of the Mineral Leasing Act. Payments are made to States without limitations, similar to payments under section 35 of the Mineral Leasing Act. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to extend the limitation on the issuance of permits until 2020. Additionally, any amount allocated to a State under section 402(g)(1)(A) that is paid as a result of a payment under this subsection will be reallocated for grants under section 402(g)(5). SEC. 3. TRANSFERS OF INTEREST EARNED BY ABANDONED MINE RECLAMATION FUND. Section 402(h) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to allow the Secretary to transfer interest earned by the fund to the United Mine Workers of America Combined Benefit Fund. The America Combined Benefit Fund and the United Mine Workers of America 1992 Benefit Plan will receive transfers based on estimated expenditures and premium receipts for the fiscal year. The 1992 Benefit Plan will receive transfers based on estimated expenditures and premium receipts for the next calendar year. The multiemployer health benefit plan established after July 20, 1992, will receive transfers based on estimated expenditures and premium receipts for the next calendar year to provide benefits no greater than those provided on the date of enactment. The trustees estimate transfers for the multiemployer health benefit plan based on expenditures and premium receipts for the upcoming calendar year. Adjustments are made if transfers are more or less than required, and previously credited interest is used for transfers to the Combined Benefit Fund. The trustees estimate transfers for the multiemployer health benefit plan based on expenditures and premium receipts for the upcoming calendar year. Previously allocated amounts, including interest, are used to offset deficits in the Combined Benefit Fund and make necessary transfers. The Secretary can make transfers for the next fiscal year only if actuarial projections show funds will be available after the transfer. Contributions from obligors determine if a transfer can be made under paragraph (2)(C). Transfers under paragraph (2)(C) must meet contribution rate requirements in effect at the time of enactment. The number of eligible beneficiaries must also be considered when determining the transfer amount. SEC. 4. PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS ACT. Transition Rules: Amounts allocated under section 402(g)(2) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 prior to the date of enactment of this Act for the program under section 406, but not appropriated, shall be available in fiscal year 2005 and thereafter for transfers as specified in section 402(h) of the Act. Interest credited to the fund established by section 401 that is not transferred to the Combined Benefit Fund shall be handled according to the amendments made by this Act. Within one year of enactment, the Secretary of the Interior will review additions to the inventory to ensure they reflect eligible lands and waters meeting specified priorities. The Secretary of the Interior will review lands and waters added to the inventory to ensure they meet specified priorities. Any areas no longer meeting criteria will be removed.
